Infrastructure / Sector: Electric substations / nuclear site off-site power
Impact (reported): Chornobyl NPP lost all off-site power after widespread military activity affected substations; switched to backup power systems (reported by IAEA).
Source title: IAEA says Ukraine's Chornobyl nuclear plant lost all off-site power on Tuesday
Key findings (from source): IAEA DG Grossi said several electrical substations vital for nuclear safety were affected; Chornobyl NPP lost all external power supply.

Infrastructure / Sector: Power supply to Exclusion Zone facilities
Impact (reported): Ukraine’s Energy Ministry said power was supplied from Ukraine’s integrated power system despite the overnight attack on infrastructure supplying the Exclusion Zone.
Source title: Chornobyl Nuclear Power Plant Supplied with Electricity from Ukraine’s Integrated Power System Despite…
Key findings (from source): Energy infrastructure supplying the Chornobyl Exclusion Zone was targeted; ministry reported continued supply from the integrated power system.

Impact (reported): Greenpeace Ukraine warned renewed attacks on nuclear-related infrastructure increase nuclear safety risks and urged stronger sanctions on Rosatom.
Source title: Greenpeace Ukraine on the electricity crisis at the Chornobyl nuclear power plant and threat to Ukraine’s operating nuclear plants
Key findings (from source): Greenpeace said attacks on substations and power supply infrastructure heighten nuclear safety risks and called for stronger action against Rosatom.

Impact (reported): IAEA reported persistent damage risk to off-site power lines; backup lines disconnected due to military activity, underlining fragility of external power supply.
Source title: Update 338 – IAEA Director General Statement on Situation in Ukraine
Key findings (from source): IAEA described off-site power vulnerabilities (incl. damaged/disconnected lines) and reiterated that substation damage undermines nuclear safety.

Impact (reported): Ukraine’s grid operator said the energy situation significantly worsened after recent air attacks, triggering emergency power outages in most regions.
Source title: Ukraine's grid operator says energy situation has 'significantly' worsened
Key findings (from source): Ukrenergo said the system deteriorated after attacks and emergency outages were introduced in most regions; officials cited the hardest day since 2022 blackout.

Impact (reported): DTEK CEO said Ukraine is nearing a humanitarian catastrophe due to strikes; called for an 'energy ceasefire' in any peace deal.
Source title: Ukraine needs energy ceasefire as catastrophe looming, top power executive says
Key findings (from source): DTEK’s CEO said repeated strikes are pushing Ukraine toward humanitarian catastrophe; argued any peace track must halt attacks on energy infrastructure.

Impact (reported): Large wave of strikes hit major cities and damaged energy infrastructure; authorities reported extensive shelling and emergency outages.
Source title: Ukraine facing emergency power cuts after Russian strikes on energy infrastructure
Key findings (from source): Strikes damaged energy infrastructure and triggered emergency power cuts; reporting highlighted wide geographic impact and civilian disruption.

Impact (reported): The Guardian reported major drone/missile attacks on the two largest cities amid peace talks, with officials framing it as terror against critical infrastructure.
Source title: Russia launches 'brutal' attack on Ukraine as peace talks continue
Key findings (from source): Reported major overnight strikes on Kyiv/Kharkiv and referenced impacts on critical infrastructure during ongoing peace talks in the UAE.

Impact (reported): Reuters reported large numbers of apartment blocks still without heating after the Jan 24–25 strike wave, highlighting prolonged winter-time service disruption.
Source title: Around 1,700 Kyiv apartment blocks still without heating after Russian strike
Key findings (from source): After the large-scale attack on Kyiv’s energy system, authorities reported persistent heating outages across thousands of buildings during sub-zero weather.

Impact (reported): NV reported Russian drones struck multiple locations; scheduled rolling blackouts and industrial limits applied while crews restored damaged lines.
Source title: Russian attacks hit energy facilities leaving parts of Ukraine without power
Key findings (from source): Authorities reported numerous drone strikes and damage; scheduled outages resumed as crews repaired power lines and stabilized supply in Kyiv region.

Impact (reported): DTEK highlighted global media focus at Davos and argued decentralized systems and defenses are critical; reiterated call for an energy ceasefire.
Source title: Global media spotlight Ukraine's energy frontline at Davos
Key findings (from source): DTEK said energy facilities remain under heavy attack and emphasized resilience measures (decentralization, defenses) while urging an energy ceasefire.

Impact (reported): ISW noted Trump statement about a week-long moratorium on some energy strikes; highlighted uncertainty and strategic implications.
Source (publisher): Institute for the Study of War
Source title: Russian Offensive Campaign Assessment, January 29, 2026
Key findings (from source): ISW reported claims of a temporary moratorium on some energy strikes and assessed how it might affect Russia’s broader campaign and negotiations.

Impact (reported): Reuters reported both sides halted air attacks on Ukrainian energy installations until Feb 1, though details and timeframe were contested.
Source title: Russia, Ukraine halt energy strikes, but differences emerge
Key findings (from source): Reported a temporary halt on air attacks on energy installations until Feb 1; noted disagreements on timeframe and continued broader hostilities.

Impact (reported): IAEA DG noted offsite supply depends on crucial substations and damage undermines nuclear safety—framing energy infrastructure protection as a safety priority.
Source title: IAEA Director General's Introductory Statement to the Board of Governors – 30 January 2026
Key findings (from source): Grossi stressed that damage to substations supplying NPP off-site power threatens nuclear safety; urged focus on protecting external supply.

Impact (reported): Ukraine’s PM said a technical failure on transmission lines triggered cascading outages, compounding stress on a grid already battered by attacks.
Source title: Shmyhal explains cause of emergency power outages in Ukraine
Key findings (from source): Shmyhal said a fault on cross-border and domestic lines triggered cascading outages; highlighted fragility of the system under wartime strain.

Impact (reported): Reuters reported January imports rose ~40% to a wartime record (ExPro), reflecting sustained damage and need for external balancing.
Source title: Ukraine's electricity imports jump 40% to record 894 gigawatt-hours in January
Key findings (from source): ExPro data showed record January imports amid constant attacks; Hungary largest share; imports up across most directions.

Impact (reported): Reuters reported Zelenskyy said Russia largely observed the energy ceasefire since it began, though both sides disputed the end date/timeframe.
Source title: Zelenskiy says Russia largely observing energy ceasefire
Key findings (from source): Zelenskyy said no targeted strikes on major energy infrastructure since the pause began; noted disagreement over how long it should last.

Impact (reported): Kyiv Independent reported a mass attack across Ukraine signaling the end of the energy ceasefire; emergency outages and heating disruptions followed.
Source title: Russia launches mass attack across Ukraine, signaling end of energy ceasefire
Key findings (from source): Reported large-scale strikes and damage to energy equipment; Kyiv introduced emergency outages; hundreds of buildings reportedly left without heating.

Impact (reported): Reuters quoted Ukraine’s energy minister saying a Kyiv power plant was badly damaged, underscoring continued degradation of generation capacity.
Source title: Ukrainian energy minister says Kyiv power plant badly damaged
Key findings (from source): Energy minister reported severe damage at a Kyiv power plant following strikes, illustrating continued pressure on generation and heat supply.

Infrastructure / Sector: Energy Support Fund / grid & heat recovery
Impact (reported): Energy Community said Ireland contributed EUR 25m (total EUR 27m) to Ukraine Energy Support Fund to help recovery amid winter strain.
Source title: Ireland backs Ukraine’s energy recovery, with total support to the Ukraine Energy Support Fund now at EUR 27 million
Key findings (from source): Energy Community reported Ireland’s contribution to the fund, citing unprecedented winter strain and the need for equipment and repairs.
